body: I have a similar issue. The model that used to work suddenly broke because of missing `scipy`.

Looks like the conda.yaml file generated in the model artifacts folder installs scikit-learn using pip instead of conda due to changes in https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/releases/tag/v1.13.1 . As a workaround, either manually modify conda.yaml and add scipy as a dependency or downgrade mlflow to 1.13.

I'm investigating this issue but `scipy` should be installed with `scikit-learn`, right?

```
>>> pip show scikit-learn
Name: scikit-learn
Version: 0.24.0
Summary: A set of python modules for machine learning and data mining
Home-page: http://scikit-learn.org
Author: None
Author-email: None
License: new BSD
Location: /Users/harutakakawamura/.pyenv/versions/miniconda3-4.7.12/envs/mlflow-dev-env/lib/python3.6/site-packages
Requires: scipy, joblib, numpy, threadpoolctl ‚≠êÔ∏è
```

@harupy Not sure. Documentation [here](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/developers/advanced_installation.html) suggests that dependencies are installed automatically by pip. But whenever I run `models serve` command, I keep getting "Module Not Found" error. 

```
File "/home/ec2-user/anaconda3/envs/mlflow-fd2774e76e23e9f22d496d4996863e8a619ce698/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sklearn/base.py", line 11, in <module>
from scipy import sparse
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'scipy'
```

Adding scipy to pip dependencies fixed the problem for me. I posted a PR to add scipy to pip dependencies list - https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/3977 . Can you please check it?

I wasn't able to repro the issue.

```python
# a.py

import mlflow

from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
from sklearn.linear_model import ElasticNet


def create_serve_command(model_uri):
    return f"mlflow models serve -m {model_uri} -p 1234"


def main():
    X, y = load_iris(return_X_y=True)
    model = ElasticNet().fit(X, y)

    with mlflow.start_run():
        mlflow.sklearn.log_model(model, "model")
        model_uri = mlflow.get_artifact_uri("model")
        print(create_serve_command(model_uri))


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

```sh
>>> eval $(python a.py)
...
[2021-01-14 13:09:34 +0900] [97498] [INFO] Starting gunicorn 20.0.4
[2021-01-14 13:09:34 +0900] [97498] [INFO] Listening at: http://127.0.0.1:1234 (97498)
[2021-01-14 13:09:34 +0900] [97498] [INFO] Using worker: sync
[2021-01-14 13:09:34 +0900] [97501] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 97501
```

not sure if this is related but https://scikit-learn.org/stable/install.html#installing-the-latest-release says

> If you have not installed NumPy or SciPy yet, you can also install these using conda or pip. When using pip, please ensure that binary wheels are used, and NumPy and SciPy are not recompiled from source, which can happen when using particular configurations of operating system and hardware (such as Linux on a Raspberry Pi).

In my environment (macbook pro), `pip install scikit-learn` installs `scipy`.

```
>>> pip install -U scikit-learn
Requirement already satisfied: scikit-learn in ... (0.24.0)
Requirement already satisfied: scipy>=0.19.1 in ... (from scikit-learn) (1.5.2)  <- üî•
Requirement already satisfied: numpy>=1.13.3 in ... (from scikit-learn) (1.19.5)
Requirement already satisfied: threadpoolctl>=2.0.0 in ... (from scikit-learn) (2.1.0)
Requirement already satisfied: joblib>=0.11 in ... (from scikit-learn) (0.17.0)
Requirement already satisfied: numpy>=1.13.3 in ... (from scikit-learn) (1.19.5)
```

My conda environment has the required libraries
```
sklearn.__version__
'0.19.1'
scipy.__version__
'1.1.0'
```
`mlflow run .` also works fine.

The error only appears when I serve the model. Conda file for the model artifact from the tutorial is as follows.
```
$ cat mlruns/0/3e27453438c14332b709e27ffe7438ad/artifacts/model/conda.yaml

channels:
- defaults
- conda-forge
dependencies:
- python=3.6.12
- pip
- pip:
  - mlflow
  - scikit-learn==0.19.1
  - cloudpickle==1.6.0
name: mlflow-env
```
If I add scipy under pip dependencies in the above file, `models serve` command would work again. 
When trying to reproduce the issue, were you trying the serve cli command? 
```
mlflow models serve -m mlruns/0/3e27453438c14332b709e27ffe7438ad/artifacts/model -p 1234 
```

I was able to repro the issue using our `sklearn_elastic_wine` example. Let me just unpin `scikit-learn` (I think `0.19.1` is too old and doesn't install `scipy`) and see if the error still persists.

EDIT

I was able to serve the model after unpinning `scikit-learn`.

It was working fine when sklearn was set as a conda dependency before [this change](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/3896). I'm not sure why adding it under pip would cause this issue. You can either revert that change or check my PR to add scipy as an additional pip dependency.

```
# Create a clean env
>>> conda create -n fresh python=3.6
>>> conda activate fresh

# pip
>>> pip install 'scikit-learn==0.19.1'
Collecting scikit-learn==0.19.1
  Using cached scikit_learn-0.19.1-cp36-cp36m-macosx_10_6_intel.macosx_10_9_intel.macosx_10_9_x86_64.macosx_10_10_intel.macosx_10_10_x86_64.whl (7.6 MB)
Installing collected packages: scikit-learn
Successfully installed scikit-learn-0.19.1

=> install only scikit-learn

# conda
>>> conda install -c conda-forge 'scikit-learn=0.19.1'
...
The following NEW packages will be INSTALLED:

  blas               conda-forge/osx-64::blas-1.1-openblas
  libgfortran        conda-forge/osx-64::libgfortran-3.0.1-0
  numpy              conda-forge/osx-64::numpy-1.15.2-py36_blas_openblashd3ea46f_1
  openblas           conda-forge/osx-64::openblas-0.2.20-8
  python_abi         conda-forge/osx-64::python_abi-3.6-1_cp36m
  scikit-learn       conda-forge/osx-64::scikit-learn-0.19.1-py36_blas_openblas_201
  scipy              conda-forge/osx-64::scipy-1.1.0-py36_blas_openblash7943236_201 üî•

=> install other dependencies
```
@neo-anderson Would you be interested in fixing the wine example (unpin + doc fix)?

@harupy Unpinning sklearn fixed the issues and I was able to serve the model.
Should I pin the latest version so that future changes wont break the tutorial?
